body:
The terror attacks in Paris have injected an emotional and unexpected element into the U.S. presidential race. But they are likely to affect the two parties in different ways.
In the Republican nomination race, as our colleagues Peter Nicholas and Beth Reinhard write, the apparent reach of ISIS terror machinery into Europe is likely to throw new attention onto the fact that the two leading GOP candidates, Donald Trump and Ben Carson, have no experience in government service or national security.
That opens the question of whether GOP primary voters will re-evaluate government experience as a qualification for office and give a second hearing to the struggling Jeb Bush and Chris Christie, both veteran political leaders, or greater consideration to Marco Rubio, who has cast himself as a foreign policy hawk and a student of international affairs.
Those candidates may now be more eager to campaign on their time in public office.
Democrats, by contrast, appear close to settling on the candidate with the most foreign policy experience in their field, Hillary Clinton. Her challenge now will be to preserve her time in office as a political asset, when Republicans will be saying the administration she served help create the instability that gave rise to ISIS.
The terror attacks will also play out differently within the two parties because each puts a different emphasis on national security as a campaign issue.
Republicans consistently rank it at or near the top of the priority list; Democrats put it well below economic concerns.
The latest Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll, conducted in late October, makes the point: Asked to name the top two issues deciding their vote for president, Democrats named the economy, social issues and values, and then health care. For Republicans, foreign policy and the Middle East were the second-most important issue, just after the economy.
Similarly, Democrats in a June Journal/NBC News survey listed two economic issuesâa shrinking middle class and power wielded by the wealthyâwhen asked which trends alarmed them the most. Republicans listed terrorism as their second-highest cause for alarm, after declining moral values.
That suggests that the issue will play out far differently within the two partiesâa development already seen in the hours after the Paris attack.
Democratic candidates walked gingerly in their debate Saturday night, calling for the U.S. to play a leadership role in battling ISIS but giving few details of how it should proceed. None of the candidatesânot Mrs. Clinton, Sen. Bernie Sanders or Martin OâMalley, a former Maryland governorâcalled for committing troops.
Mrs. Clinton did not mention one element of Syria policy where she differs from her rivals and from President Barack Obama. She backs a no-fly zone and âhumanitarian corridorsââ to protect civilians caught in the fighting; the president doesnât.
One question now is whether Democratic voters develop a greater appetite for tougher steps against ISIS, perhaps involving U.S. troops, and whether Mrs. Clinton and her rivals try to lead them to such a position. A similar question holds for independent voters, who also have ranked national security and terrorism relatively low on the priority list, at least until now.
Republicans over the weekend detailed more forceful steps they would take against ISIS. Mr. Rubio said NATO should invoke Article 5âits collective defense provision, which obligates signatories to defend a nation that has been attacked. Mr. Rubio said this would bring Western allies together and âput together a coalition to confront this challenge.ââ
Mr. Bush said the U.S. should âdeclare war and harness all of the power that the United States can bring to bear, both diplomatic and military.â
Mr.Â Trump has previously taken an assertive posture against ISIS, saying in a recently published book that âmassive forceââ is necessary and that he would send âa limitedâbut sufficient number of troops to fight on the groundâ against ISIS, if military advisers recommended it.
“We would hit them so hard and so fast in so many different ways, they wouldnât know what happened,ââ Mr. Trump promised.
As the polling shows, those are words likely to resonate far better among Mr. Trumpâs own party than among Democrats.

description: The terror attacks in Paris have injected an emotional and unexpected element into the U.S. presidential race. But they are likely to affect the two parties in different ways.
title: Paris Attacks Upend White House Race in Different Ways for Each Party
